statement.tex: If the function $f:\R\to\R$ be defined as $f(x) = 2x-3$ and $g:\R\to\R$ be defined as $g(x) = x^3 + 5$, then find the value of \[ \qquad\qquad \ifgx \]

reason.tex:
%text In $ y= \fgx$, we know $x$ (independent variable) and use $\fgx$ to find $y$ (dependent variable) But to \underline\text{find $x$ given $y$}, we need the inverse function $\ifgy$ which we can find as follows % \begin{align}
y = 2x^3 + 7 &\implies x = \sqrt[3]{\dfrac{y-7}{2}} \\ \therefore \left(f\circ g \right)^{-1}(y) &= x = \sqrt[3]{\dfrac{y-7}{2}} \end{align} %text But \underline\text{by convention}, the \underline\text{independent} variable is written as $x$ and the \underline\text{dependent} variable as $y$. Hence, \[ \qquad \ifgx = \sqrt[3]{\dfrac{x-7}{2}} \] %
